importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date the article was updated, indicating the most current information available on the status of the Trump-Putin summit plans.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This timeframe was originally proposed by Trump following a phone call with Putin, but has since been abandoned due to lack of progress and divergent positions between US and Russian officials.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump’s hopes for a quick summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin have stalled.
There are now no plans for a Trump-Putin summit in the immediate future, according to an administration official.

A prior phone call between US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov was described as productive, but did not move the process forward due to divergent expectations on ending the Ukraine war.
The Kremlin argued that no date was set for a summit, so it cannot be postponed.
Russian officials have rejected the idea of freezing the conflict, which was proposed by Trump after a meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.
Ukrainian President Zelensky claims that Russia has become less interested in diplomacy after the US declined to provide Ukraine with long-range Tomahawk missiles.
Zelensky asserts that greater Ukrainian long-range capabilities are necessary for increased Russian willingness to end the war.

The US administration believes that high-level talks between Rubio and Lavrov are not essential because Lavrov is not involved in key decision-making and is seen as loyal to Putin but not capable of driving progress.
There remains a possibility that Rubio and Lavrov could meet at an ASEAN-led summit next week in Malaysia.
Trump remains committed to brokering peace in Ukraine, emphasizing that he wants to stop the war and find a diplomatic solution.
European leaders and Ukraine support Trump’s call to stop the war at the current battle line.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump's proposed quick summit with Putin has become a central topic of discussion, reflecting his ongoing efforts to resolve the Ukraine war through diplomacy.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the key counterpart to Trump in the proposed summit and represents the Russian government’s position on the Ukraine conflict.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio is engaged in diplomatic discussions with Lavrov to lay groundwork for a Trump-Putin summit, though those efforts have stalled.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is central to current diplomatic backchannel talks, though his influence is seen as limited due to lack of involvement in key Russian decisions.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky has publicly linked the lack of long-range missile support from the U.S. to Russia’s reduced interest in diplomacy and peace negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov represents the Kremlin’s official stance, stating that a summit cannot be postponed if no date was set.

namedEntities.name: Mark Rutte
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is scheduled to meet Rutte at the White House, indicating broader diplomatic engagement beyond the Trump-Putin summit.

namedEntities.name: ASEAN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ASEAN is mentioned as a potential venue for future Rubio-Lavrov meetings, showing alternative diplomatic channels for engagement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump’s plan for a rapid summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin has stalled, with the White House now confirming no immediate plans for a meeting. This follows a previous phone call between Trump and Putin that suggested a meeting within two weeks, but diplomatic progress stalled after a call between US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, which revealed divergent positions on ending the war in Ukraine. The Kremlin has stated that a summit cannot be postponed without a scheduled date, while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky argues that Russia's reduced interest in diplomacy stems from the US withholding long-range missiles. Despite the setback, the US maintains that Trump remains committed to peace in Ukraine, and there remains a possibility for future talks between Rubio and Lavrov at a regional forum like ASEAN’s upcoming summit in Malaysia.
title: Trump’s hopes for quick second summit with Putin have stalled out
